title: 110_s2455
content:
The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additional emergency CDBG funding is addressed in the Act. $1,000,000,000 is appropriated for assistance to States, cities, and counties for community development block grants, including foreclosure-related expenses and rental assistance. The $1 billion appropriation is for community development block grants, including foreclosure-related expenses and rental assistance. Funds cannot be used for individual homeowner foreclosure prevention purposes, except for counseling services. The $1 billion appropriation for community development block grants can be provided directly to certified housing counseling services approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 3 of the Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25%. SEC. 4 states that at least 50% of the funds must benefit low- and moderate-income individuals. SEC. 5 outlines plans and reports. (a) Comprehensive Plan.--Funds under this Act require a detailed plan for approval by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
(b) Report on Use of Funds.--Recipients must submit quarterly reports accounting for the use of funds. Urban counties receiving funds under this Act must submit quarterly reports to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development detailing the use of the funds. SEC. 6. WAIVERS. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive certain provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds, upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county, as long as it does not conflict with the overall purpose of the statute. Waiver may be granted by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for the use of funds, upon request by a State, metropolitan city, or urban county, if it aligns with the statute's purpose. Waivers can include the 50 percent requirement and public service requirement cap, based on a demonstrated compelling need. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive the public service requirement cap upon request if a compelling need is shown. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before taking effect and will be reviewed by the Secretary. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may grant waivers to the public service requirement cap if a compelling need is demonstrated. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before taking effect and will be reviewed and potentially reauthorized by the Secretary every 2 years. The Secretary must also notify the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any waivers granted or denied under this section within 5 days. The Senate and House Committees on Appropriations must be notified of any waivers granted or denied under this section at least 5 days before the decision is made. SEC. 7. Noncompliance with community development requirements under this Act will be subject to the provisions of section 111 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8. GAO will conduct an audit. SEC. 8. GAO will conduct an audit of funds appropriated under this Act and submit a report to the Senate and House committees. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must provide quarterly reports to the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations regarding the use of funds, including the number of households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, certified housing counseling services, and any other relevant information. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must provide quarterly reports to Congress on the use of funds for counseling assistance and steps taken to prevent fraud and abuse.
